reason: We've done some fun history rewriting.
description:
This is the very large PR summing up the work that @samskillman and I did last week on the FITS frontend, along with some changes to particle trajectories. I don't want this to go in just yet--it needs documentation and I wanted to start the discussion rolling on it first. 

Flagging for unitless datasets
-------------------------------------------

First, the small change that is the most important. There are a wide variety of FITS files, which may have different units along the axes of the data cube, including quantities which are not "lengths". The most natural length unit in a FITS cube (and the only universal one) is that of the pixel. For this reason, we decided to make it the "code_length" unit equal to the pixel unit. 

This points up the fact that not all datasets will have a known cgs equivalent for "code_length", even though we nominally set 1 code_length = 1 cm in that case. I want to retain this behavior, but have some way of flagging that there is no known translation to centimeters for this dataset. 

The way I implemented this is to add a `no_cgs_equiv_length` attribute to the `Dataset` object, which is always set to `False` by default. Only in the Athena and the FITS frontends is it set to `True`, and only if length unit information is not provided. PlotWindow plots will check the value of `no_cgs_equiv_length` and if found to be true will plot the axes in units of "code length" rather than "cm". My rationale behind this is rather pedantic: I feel that plots with the axes labeled in "cm" in this case are misleading, even if the values along the axes are "correct". I welcome alternative suggestions.

FITS Files Support
----------------------------

Support for FITS files has been greatly extended. This includes the following:

1) Optimizations from reducing the number of times that the FITS data cube is accessed.   
2) yt attempts to automatically decompose the single FITS "grid" into a number of grids based on the size of the dataset. This can be overridden by supplying the `nprocs` parameter to `load`.   
3) Different image blocks within the FITS dataset are detected as different fields, and are given names based on keywords in the header.   
4) More than one file can be supplied to include multiple fields, provided they are all on the same grid structure.   
5) 4-dimensional FITS cubes, such as those including information about the Stokes parameters, are supported by accessing them as different fields.   
6) Two special cases of FITS cubes, based on the WCS information in the header, are detected. The first is where the WCS indicates a rectilinear coordinate system based on known length units. The second is where the WCS indicates an RA/Dec coordinate system, which may be a 2D image or a "PPV" cube. In the latter case, the third axis ("V") is a quantity like line-of-sight velocity, or frequency, or wavelength.   
7) WCS coordinates are supported by setting them up as fields. If the datacube is in the "PPV" format, setting up these fields is made more efficient by making the simplifying assumption that the X and Y coordinates are not dependent on V, and vice-versa.   
8) @samskillman developed an implementation for creating fields of different spectral lines based on different offsets into the third axis for PPV cubes. He's got a notebook illustrating this which should go into the docs.   
9) Two classes in `yt.utilities.fits_image`, `FITSSlice` and `FITSProjection`, take on-axis slices and projections of fields and write them to FITS files, with the WCS information included. This will enable derived fields generated in yt to be exported for use with other analysis tools.   

PPVCube Analysis Module
---------------------------------------

In tandem with the FITS frontend, and based on a suggestion from Peter Teuben, I have developed an analysis module to generate FITS cubes in "position-position-velocity" space from datasets loaded up in yt. The idea is that a normal vector is chosen along which a series of off-axis projections are made of a supplied field, where each projection is only made of that field which is associated with a particular velocity along the line of sight. This results in "intensity cubes" in position-position-velocity space that are similar to those generated from observations. An example notebook will be included in this PR as part of the docs. 

Improvements to Particle Trajectories
------------------------------------------------------

Particle trajectories have been unit-ified, and some of the earlier limitations placed on the algorithm have been removed. In particular, trajectories which start or stop in the middle of the time series (due to particles being created or leaving the domain) can now be included, and parallelization has been implemented. 

UPDATE 1: Responded to some suggestions, cleaned up `decompose_array`, added checking for consistent data shape between FITS images. Made `FITSSlice` and `FITSProjection` more general so that they can be used with any dataset, not just FITS. All tests pass on my end. Still writing docs.

UPDATE 2: Added documentation. I still don't have example data that I have been given permission to use, so answer tests and cookbooks will unfortunately have to hold off until then. Also, @samskillman needs to document his contributions.   

Some other things:   

* Changed "XYVCube" --> "PPVCube" (position-position-velocity) since this is more in line with standard terminology. 
* Now set NaN masks for all fields to any desired value, or on a per-field basis.
* Fixed a few bugs:    
1. Off-axis SZ projections and input width units   
2. Changed a stray "mpc" to "Mpc" in `get_smallest_appropriate_unit`   
3. A couple of bugs in the Athena frontend.    

I think that barring any other issues, this is ready to go in, but we obviously need more documentation. 

UPDATE 3: Forgot to set `self.nan_mask` to a dict if that's what was passed in. 

UPDATE 4: Added just a little more functionality.   

1) Now supports event data as "particle" datasets, with options for creating deposited image fields in different energy bands.     
2) Give an option to override field names and units, if necessary.   
3) Add pixel, beam, counts units. Beam is now a solid angle, the value of which needs to be passed in as a parameter.    
4) Various bug fixes and small refinements.   

Outstanding issues:

a) @MatthewTurk and I have been thinking more about how to handle coordinates, particularly along the "velocity" axis, and issues related to plotting.  
b) There is a bug with field cuts that is FITS-specific, that has to do with the way the data is decomposed into virtual grids. Somehow, the wrong cut ends up being taken, and the data limits of the resulting container are incorrect. 

Unfortunately we have to hold off on more documentation until these issues get sorted out, particularly issue b), since the docs I have devised depend on it. I have some test files that are ready to go for docs and answer testing. I would be happy to address the rest in a separate PR if people feel like this should go in now, or I'm happy to leave this open until then.
title: FITS frontend work, XYVCube analysis module, updates to Particle Trajectories

content.raw:
What do you think about returning `(None, None)` instead?  I believe that will make a plot without unit labels.  `code_length` is also fine, but if there are no units then we shouldn't plot unit labels at all, I think.

+1 on adding more support for truly unitless data.
content.html:
What do you think about returning (None, None) instead? I believe that will make a plot without unit labels. code_length is also fine, but if there are no units then we shouldn't plot unit labels at all, I think.

+1 on adding more support for truly unitless data.

content.raw: I see the point, but then again there are numbers on the axes, so whatever is being plotted is being done over a range in *something*, which will always be defined as the code length. Also, this will be different for different datasets, e.g. for FITS it will always be one pixel, but for Athena datasets it could be the the width of the domain.
content.html: I see the point, but then again there are numbers on the axes, so whatever is being plotted is being done over a range in something, which will always be defined as the code length. Also, this will be different for different datasets, e.g. for FITS it will always be one pixel, but for Athena datasets it could be the the width of the domain.

content.raw: Yes, that's correct, and it's bugged me. The problem is we don't know the beam size ahead of time. Probably the thing to do is to add the beam unit upon loading the file if it's needed, and make the conversion from beam to solid angle a passed parameter.
content.html: Yes, that's correct, and it's bugged me. The problem is we don't know the beam size ahead of time. Probably the thing to do is to add the beam unit upon loading the file if it's needed, and make the conversion from beam to solid angle a passed parameter.
